prompt:

How fast does the available amount of gold in the world increase due to mining?[/INST]
pred:
The amount of gold mined annually around the world has fluctuated over time, but on average, global gold mining production has increased at a slow pace. According to the World Gold Council (WGC), the total gold mined from 1900 to 2019 was around 192,000 metric tonnes.

Historically, gold mining production has increased at an average rate of around 2% per year, although there have been significant fluctuations due to various factors such as changes in global demand, gold prices, and mining technology. For example, during the 1930s and 1940s, gold mining production significantly increased due to the rise in gold prices caused by the Great Depression and World War II. Similarly, in the 1990s and 2000s, gold mining production grew rapidly due to the expansion of gold mining operations in South Africa, Russia, and China.

However, it's important to note that the rate of increase in gold mining production has slowed down in recent years due to various factors such as declining gold grades, increasing production costs, and environmental concerns. According to the WGC, global gold mining production is expected to average around 3,300 metric tonnes per year from 2020 to 2029
answers: Approximately 5.3 billion ounces have been mined. This puts the total value of all gold in the world at about $9.5 trillion, based on $1800/oz. Total world net worth was $125T in 2006. There's an odd thing that happens when one asset's value is suddenly such a large percent of all assets. (This reminds me of how and why the tech bubble burst. Cisco and EMC would have been worth more than all other stocks combined if they grew in the 00's like they did in the 90's.) Production (in 2005/6) ran about 80 million oz/yr. Just over 1.5% impact to total supply, so you are right in that observation.  On the other hand, the limited amount out here, means that if everyone decided to put their wealth in gold, it would be done by driving the price to bubblicious levels.  One can study this all day, and parse out how much is in investment form (as compared to jewelry, etc) and realize that a few trillion dollars in value pales in comparison to the wealth of the US alone, let alone the world. Half the world can't buy two oz if they tried.  Of course there's pressure to reopen mines that had costs pushing $800/oz. Understand that the supply of $300 gold is long gone. As the easy gold has been mined, and cost goes up, there's a point where mines close. But as the price of gold trades at these levels, the mines that couldn't produce at $600 are now opening.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can potentially affect your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, the account is typically closed and a new card with new numbers is issued. This can impact your credit utilization ratio, which is the amount of credit you're using compared to the amount of credit available to you.

In general, a reduction in available credit can have a negative impact on your credit utilization ratio, which is an important factor in determining your credit score. For example, let's say you had an outstanding balance of $500 on a credit card with a $3,000 limit. If the card is replaced and the new limit is $2,500, your credit utilization ratio increases to 50% ($500 / $2,500). A high credit utilization ratio can negatively impact your credit score.

However, it's worth noting that the impact of a lost credit card on your credit score will depend on a variety of factors, including the length of time the card was open, your payment history, and the overall diversity of your credit profile. In some cases, the loss of a credit card may not have a significant impact on your credit score.

To minimize the potential impact on your credit score, it's important to keep track of your credit card accounts and report any lost or st
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

In general, you cannot transfer money from a personal pension directly to a SIPP while leaving the original pension open. This is because transfers between pensions are subject to certain rules and regulations, and they must be carried out in a specific way to ensure that the transfer is tax-efficient and compliant with pension legislation.

Once the funds are transferred to the SIPP, you can manage the investments within the wrapper, including selecting and managing investments, and taking withdrawals in retirement.

It's important to consider the following factors before transferring money from a personal pension to a SIPP:

* Tax implications: Transfers between pensions are tax-free, but there may be tax implications to consider depending on your individual circumstances

* High credit utilization: If you are using a large portion of your available credit, it can indicate to lenders that you may have difficulty paying back your debts. A high credit utilization ratio can negatively impact your credit score, as it may indicate a higher level of risk for lenders.
* Low credit utilization: Conversely, a low credit utilization ratio can indicate that you are able to manage your credit responsibly and pay back your debts on time. This can positively impact your credit score, as it may indicate a lower level of risk for lenders.

It's important to note that credit utilization is just one of the many factors that can impact your credit score. Other factors include payment history

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When a company declares a dividend, it pays out a portion of its profits to its shareholders in the form of cash or additional shares. The dividend amount is usually expressed as a dollar amount per share, and this amount is what is actually paid out to shareholders.

However, the dividend quote or dividend yield equation, which is used to calculate the annual dividend payment per share based on the current stock price, does not include withheld taxes. This is because the withheld taxes are not actually paid out to shareholders, but rather are deducted from the dividend payment by the company before it is distributed to shareholders.

To calculate the after-tax dividend payment, you would need to subtract the withheld taxes from the dividend payment. For example, if a company declares a dividend of $1 per share and the withheld tax rate is 25%, the after-tax dividend payment would be $0.75 per share ($1 - $0.25 = $0.75).

It's worth noting that the withheld tax rate can vary depending on the type of stock and the individual shareholder's tax situation. For example, some stocks may have a lower withh
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

prompt:

Does the low CAD positively or negatively impact Canadian Investors?[/INST]
pred:
A low Canadian Alternative to the US dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors, depending on their investment strategies and objectives.

Positive impacts:

1. Export competitiveness: A low CAD can make Canadian exports cheaper for foreign buyers, leading to increased demand and higher sales for Canadian businesses. This can positively impact the Canadian economy and lead to job creation.
2. Investment returns: Canadian investors may see higher returns on their investments in foreign assets, such as stocks or real estate, as the CAD depreciates. This is because these assets are denominated in US dollars, which will appreciate relative to the CAD.
3. Tourism: A low CAD can make Canada more attractive to international tourists, which can boost spending in the tourism industry and support local businesses.

Negative impacts:

1. Inflation: A low CAD can lead to higher imports and inflation, as foreign goods become cheaper and more accessible to Canadians. This can erode purchasing power and reduce the value of Canadian investments.
2. Interest rates: A low CAD can lead to higher interest rates in Canada, as the Bank of Canada may raise rates to combat inflation and maintain economic stability. Higher interest rates can negatively impact borrowing and invest
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm happy to provide you with information on stop-loss as a risk management tool. Stop-loss is a financial derivative that enables investors to limit their potential losses by fixing the price at which they will sell a security if it falls below a certain level.

In terms of safety, stop-loss orders can be an effective way to manage risk in financial markets. By setting a stop-loss order at a certain price level, investors can limit their potential losses if the price of the security they are holding declines beyond that level. For example, if an investor buys 100 shares of XYZ stock at $50 per share and sets a stop-loss order at $40, they will automatically sell the stock if it falls to $40 or lower, limiting their potential loss to $10 per share.

However, it's important to understand that stop-loss orders are not foolproof. There are several reasons why a stop-loss order may not be executed at the expected price:

1. Market volatility: If the price of the security moves rapidly, there may not be enough time for the stop-loss order to be executed at the specified price.
2. Market gaps: If the price of the security gaps below the stop-loss price, the order may not be executed until the gap is filled, which could take some time
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. To overcome this challenge, HFT firms typically maintain a "Collateral Account" that holds the funds required to settle trades. answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. For example, the United States Oil Fund (USO) tracks the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude oil, while the Vanguard Energy ETF (VDE) tracks a broader index of energy companies.

Related hedges, also known as "economic hedges," are financial instruments used to manage risks associated with specific economic factors, such as interest rates, currencies, or commodity prices. There are several types of related hedges, including:

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all types of financial instruments that are commonly confused with each other. However, they have distinct differences in terms of their characteristics, risks, and benefits. Here's a brief overview of each:

1. Convertible Debt:
Convertible debt is a type of debt instrument that can be converted into equity shares of the issuer at a later date, usually at the investor's option. This feature allows investors to benefit from both the security of debt and the potential upside of equity. Convertible debt typically has a fixed interest rate and a maturity date, after which it can be converted into shares.
2. Notes:
Notes are similar to bonds but are typically unsecured and have a shorter maturity period, usually ranging from 1 to 10 years. Like bonds, notes pay a fixed rate of interest and return the principal amount at maturity. Notes are often issued by companies to raise capital for various purposes.
3. Bonds:
Bonds are also unsecured debt instruments that pay a fixed rate of interest and return the principal amount at maturity. Bonds can be issued for a variety of purposes, including financing a company's operations, expanding its business, or funding a specific project. They are generally considered to be less
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

If you make a purchase that exceeds your credit limit, the excess amount will be carried over to the next billing cycle and subject to interest charges.

In this case, the interest is calculated on the entire amount that exceeds your credit limit, not just the portion that is deducted from your available credit limit. answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

Yes, an exchange-traded fund (ETF) can perform differently than its holdings. This phenomenon is known as "ETF tracking difference" or "ETF discount/premium." Here are some reasons why an ETF may deviate from its holdings:

1. Market impact: When an ETF trades on an exchange, it buys and sells its underlying assets at prevailing market prices, which may differ from the net asset value (NAV) of the ETF's holdings. This can lead to a temporary discrepancy between the ETF's price and the NAV of its holdings.

4. Rebalancing: ETFs may periodically rebalance their portfolios to maintain their target allocations. This process can result in buying or selling securities
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

When someone starts a bank, they normally get together a bunch of investors -- perhaps people they know personally, perhaps they sell stock -- to raise initial capital. But most of the money in the bank comes from depositors. Fundamentally, what a bank does is take money from depositors and loan it to borrowers. (Banks also borrow money from other banks and from the government.) They charge the borrowers interest on the loan, and they pay depositors interest on their deposits. The difference between those two interest rates is where the bank gets their profit. Where does the money go when you pay it back? prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How do UK Gilts interest rates and repayments work?[/INST]
pred:
Sure, I'd be happy to help!

UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the UK government to borrow money from investors. The interest rate on Gilts is determined by the market forces of supply and demand, and is set at the auction when the government issues the bond. The interest rate is typically fixed for the life of the bond, which can range from 10 to 30 years.

The way it works is that the government issues a bond, and investors bid for the right to hold that bond. The bid price is the price at which the investor agrees to buy the bond, and the interest rate is the rate at which the investor agrees to lend the money to the government. The government then pays the investor a fixed rate of interest, known as the coupon rate, on the face value of the bond.

For example, let's say the government issues a bond with a face value of £1,000 and a fixed coupon rate of 3%. The investor will receive £1,000 in principal at the end of the bond's term, and will also receive £30 in interest each year, paid at the coupon rate.

As for repayments, when the bond matures, the government will repay the investor the face value of the bond, plus any accrued interest. For
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

In the United States, gift giving for tax purposes typically falls within one of two categories: cash and non-cash gifts.

Cash gifts, including checks, money orders, and direct bank transfers, are considered taxable income for the recipient in the year received, regardless of when the gift is given. For example, if you give your spouse a $1,000 cash gift on December 24th, 2022, it will be considered taxable income for your spouse in 2022.

Non-cash gifts, such as stocks, bonds, mutual funds, real estate, and personal property, are considered taxable income for the recipient in the year they are transferred or given, regardless of when the gift is made. For example, if you give your child a piece of real estate on December 1st, 2022, it will be considered taxable income for your child in 2022, even if you paid for it in prior years.

This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual".  Therefore, if I gift my child $14,000 by writing a check on 12/31/2014 but they deposit it on 1/3/2015 then I have used my annual gift exclusion for 2015 and not 2014. If I give $14,000 of cash to my child and then also give them Christmas gifts with a value of $1,000 I have exceeded my annual gift exclusion to that child.  Usually there are ways around this issue as I can give $14,000 to each and every person I want and if married my spouse can do the same.  This allows us to give $14,000 from each of us to each child plus $14,000 from each of us to their spouse if married and $14,000 from each of us to each of their children if they have any.

In the financial market, options are contracts that give the buyer the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specified price (strike price) within a specified time frame. Options are often used as a hedging tool to protect against potential losses or as a speculative investment.

When purchasing options, investors typically have the option to either buy a call option or a put option, depending on their market outlook. answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. Or you tell the broker what the limits are that you consider acceptable, trading these risks off against each other. Pick the one which comes closest to your intent and ignore the fact that others may be getting a slightly different price. That's just the way the market works. Bad Debt:
Bad debt, also known as "consumer debt," refers to debt that does not provide a long-term financial benefit and can negatively impact your financial situation. Examples of bad debt include:

* Credit card debt: Using credit cards for non-essential purchases can lead to debt accumulation and high interest charges.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs/Mutual Funds. The wash sale rule is a tax rule that aims to prevent investors from claiming a loss on the sale of an investment without actually realizing a loss in their investment. The rule applies when an investor sells a security at a loss and buys substantially identical security, or a security representing the same investment, within 30 days before or after the sale.

For stocks, the wash sale rule is straightforward. If you sell a stock at a loss and buy the same or substantially identical stock within 30 days, the IRS will disregard the loss for tax purposes. This means that you will not be able to claim a loss on your taxes for that sale. However, you can still pick up the stock at a lower price and sell it at a higher price later, realizing a gain on your investment.

For ETFs/Mutual Funds, the wash sale rule is a bit different. Instead of focusing on the identical security, the rule looks at whether the new investment has "economic substantiality" to the original investment. This means that if you sell an ETF/Mutual Fund at a loss and buy a new ETF/Mutual Fund with similar investment objectives and holdings within
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

Biweekly mortgage payments are a popular option for homeowners who want to save money on their mortgage interest and pay off their home faster. However, there are some potential catches to consider before implementing this strategy.

One catch is that biweekly payments may not always result in faster payoff. Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are related concepts in real estate investing.

Capitalization rate (Cap Rate) is the ratio of net operating income (NOI) to property value, expressed as a percentage. It is used to estimate the return on investment for a real estate property. Cap Rate is calculated by dividing the property's annual NOI by its purchase price or market value. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and a purchase price of $1 million, the Cap Rate would be 10% ($100,000 / $1 million = 0.10).

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a financial metric used to assess a company's overall profitability. It is calculated by dividing the company's net profit by its revenue, expressed as a percentage. Net profit margin helps investors evaluate a company's ability to generate profits compared to its expenses.

While both Cap Rate and net profit margin provide useful information for real estate investors, they are used in different contexts. Cap Rate is a tool for evaluating the potential return on investment for a specific property, while net profit margin is a broader metric used for evaluating a company's overall financial performance.

In summary, while

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
In the forex market, a "lot" refers to a standardized unit of measurement for trading currency pairs. The most common lot size is the standard lot, which is equal to 100,000 units of the base currency (e.g. EUR for EUR/USD). This means that if you are trading EUR/USD, one lot is equal to 100,000 euros.

It's worth noting that there are other lot sizes available, such as the mini lot, which is equal to 10,000 units of the base currency (i.e. 10 mini lots = 1 standard lot). Mini lots are popular among beginner traders and those who want to trade with smaller capital.

It's also important to understand that the lot size you trade affects your potential profit and loss, as well as the risk associated with your trades. Trading one lot of EUR/USD, for example, means that you are potentially exposed to $100,000 worth of currency fluctuations. If the EUR/USD exchange rate moves in your favor, you could potentially make a profit of $100,000; if it moves against you, you could lose up to $100,000.

In summary, one "lot" of
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]

Restricted stock units (RSUs) are taxed as ordinary income when they are vesting or settled, and can be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment in certain situations. Here's a breakdown of how RSUs are taxed and the conditions under which they may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment:

Vesting and Settlement:
When RSUs vest, the employee receives the underlying stock or cash equivalent, and the income is taxed as ordinary income at that time. The taxable amount is based on the fair market value of the stock on the vesting date.

Long-term Capital Gains Treatment:
Once an RSU is settled, the employee may have the opportunity to sell the stock and realize a capital gain. If the stock is held for more than one year after the vesting date, the gain may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment. This means that the tax rate applied to the gain would be lower than the ordinary income tax rate.

Consequences of Holding RSUs Until Death:

The world, in aggregate, generates a non-zero return through the concept of compounding. Compounding refers to the idea that the earnings of an investment are reinvested to generate more earnings, leading to an exponential increase in wealth over time.

To understand how compounding works, let's consider an example. Imagine you invest $100 in a savings account that pays an annual interest rate of 5%. At the end of the first year, you earn $5 in interest, leaving you with a total of $105. In the second year, you earn interest on the entire $105, not just the initial $100. So, you earn $5.25 in interest (5% of $105), bringing your total to $110.25.

This pattern of earning interest on both the initial investment and the accumulated interest continues each year, leading to a rapid increase in wealth over time. The power of compounding is that small differences in interest rates or time can result in significant returns over the long term.

prompt:

What is a subsidy?[/INST]
pred:
A subsidy is a financial assistance or support provided by a government or organization to promote a particular activity, industry, or product. The primary purpose of a subsidy is to reduce the costs or increase the revenue of a business, industry, or individual, with the aim of achieving a specific policy or economic goal.

Subsidies can take various forms, including direct payments, tax breaks, loan guarantees, or marketing support. For example, a government may provide a subsidy to farmers to encourage them to produce crops that are in short supply or to promote agricultural research and development. Similarly, a subsidy may be provided to a manufacturing company to encourage it to invest in new technology or to move its operations to a rural area.

Subsidies can have both positive and negative effects on the economy. On the one hand, they can stimulate economic growth, create jobs, and promote competition by reducing costs and increasing efficiency. On the other hand, they can also lead to market distortion, inefficiency, and overproduction, as businesses may focus on exploiting the subsidy rather than producing goods or services at a reasonable cost.

It is important to note that subsidies are not the same as grants or bailouts, which are forms of direct financial assistance provided to individuals or businesses in times of need. Subsidies are
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it a bet on price fluctuations and against the house?[/INST]
pred:
In a casino, a player placing a "bet" on a game such as craps is not necessarily betting on price fluctuations. Instead, they are placing a wager against the house, which means they are betting that a specific outcome will occur.

In craps, players can place various bets on the outcome of the game, such as the outcome of a roll, the outcome of a series of rolls, or the outcome of a specific part of the game. These bets are against the house, meaning that if the player wins, the house loses. The house edge is built into the betting odds, which means that over time, the house is likely to make a profit from the bets placed by players.

For example, if a player places a bet on the "pass line" in craps, they are betting that the shooter will roll a 7 or 11 on the come-out roll. If the shooter rolls a 2, 3, or 12, the player loses. The odds of winning for the player are 60.3% for this bet, which means the house edge is 39.7%.

In summary, when playing games like craps, players are not betting on price fluctuations, but rather against the house, with the odds and payouts set by the casino
answers: The answer depends on the specific instrument to which you are referring. It is possible to make straight bets that are cash-settled and in which the underlying commodity or instrument will never be bought or sold.  It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. It is possible to make trades with a brokerage firm such that the firm pays if the trader wins the bet.  The firm will typically find parties on the other side to even out this bet and leave itself neutral as to the outcome (plus a small premium it charges each side for the cost of making the market).  The cost charged to one contracting party should be set by the dealer in relation to prices being charged to parties making the opposite, matching bet (in this way, brokers are following market price, while traders are setting it). Financially, options and contracts can be settled for cash or for the underlying, and they can be made directly with the opposite bettor or with a neutral dealer.

answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

prompt:

What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial investment strategy that involves selling securities that the investor does not own with the expectation of buying them back at a lower price to realize a profit. In essence, the investor is "borrowing" the securities from a broker and selling them at the current market price, with the intention of buying them back later and returning them to the lender.

To implement a short sale, an investor must identify a stock that they believe will decline in value. They then sell the stock at the current market price, while simultaneously agreeing to purchase an equivalent amount of the same stock at a later date, known as the "cover" price. The difference between the sale price and the cover price represents the profit generated by the short sale.

Short selling can be used to hedge against potential losses in a portfolio, or to bet on a decline in the price of a particular stock. However, it is important to note that short selling incurs a higher level of risk compared to buying securities outright, as the potential for unlimited losses exists if the stock price rises instead of falls.

To close a short position, the investor must purchase the originally borrowed stock at the prevailing market price and return it to the broker. If the stock price has risen, the investor
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

prompt:

Is there a return-on-investment vs risk graph anywhere?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, there are several return-on-investment (ROI) vs risk graphs available that can help investors visualize the potential return and risk associated with different investment options. Here are a few examples:

1. The Sharpe Ratio: Developed by William Sharpe, this graph plots the expected return of an investment against the risk, measured by standard deviation, of that investment. The Sharpe Ratio is a useful tool for comparing the expected return of a particular investment to its risk, and for evaluating the efficiency of an investment portfolio.
2. The Markowitz Mean-Variance Graph: This graph is a visual representation of the Markowitz model, which is a widely used framework for portfolio optimization. The graph shows the tradeoff between expected return and risk of a portfolio, and can help investors identify the optimal mix of assets to achieve their desired return and risk level.
3. The Efficient Frontier: This graph is a visual representation of the set of portfolios that achieve the highest expected return for a given level of risk, or the lowest expected risk for a given level of return. The efficient frontier can help investors identify the most efficient portfolio for their investment goals.
4. The Risk-Return Matrix: This graph is a 2D plot that shows the potential returns and risks of a investment on a matrix.

answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The IRS requires taxpayers to report their income and calculate their tax liability based on the income earned during the tax year.

Retroactively taxing gains made earlier in the fiscal year would be in violation of this principle. The U.S. Constitution grants Congress the power to lay and collect taxes, but it also imposes limits on Congress's taxation powers. The Supreme Court has consistently held that taxes must be prospective in nature, meaning they must apply to income earned in the future.

There are some exceptions to this rule, such as the "captive reorganization" doctrine, which allows the IRS to recharacterize certain transactions as occurring in the tax year in which they were taxable, rather than the year in which they were actually entered into. However, these exceptions are rare and do not generally apply to ordinary income taxes.

In summary, the U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year. Taxes must be assessed on income earned during the tax year, and the IRS is bound by the Constitution's prospective taxation

answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off. This can help ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations, as well as avoid any potential
answers: In most jurisdictions, both the goods (raw materials) and the service (class) are being "sold" to the customer, who is the end user and thus the sale is subject to sales tax. So, when your friend charges for the class, that $100 is subject to all applicable sales taxes for the jurisdiction and all parent jurisdictions (usually city, county and state). The teacher should not have to pay sales tax when they buy the flowers from the wholesaler; most jurisdictions charge sales tax on end-user purchases only. However, they are required to have some proof of sales tax exemption for the purchase, which normally comes part and parcel with the DBA or other business entity registration paperwork in most cities/states.  Wholesalers deal with non-end-user sales (exempt from sales tax) all the time, but your average Michael's or Hobby Lobby may not be able to deal with this and may have to charge your friend the sales tax at POS. Depending on the jurisdiction, if this happens, your friend may be able to reduce the amount the customer is paying that is subject to sales tax by the pre-tax value of the materials the customer has paid for, which your friend already paid the tax on.

In a no-arbitrage market, the prices of bonds and the expected future cash flows from holding those bonds should be equal across different markets and investors. This means that there is no opportunity to profit from buying bonds in one market and selling them in another, as the prices and yields would be the same.

Despite this, there are still reasons to buy bonds in a no-arbitrage market:

1. Risk reduction: Bonds typically offer lower volatility than stocks, making them a popular choice for risk-averse investors. Even in a no-arbitrage market, bonds can provide a measure of protection against market downturns.
2. Income streaming: Bonds offer a fixed rate of return in the form of interest payments, which can provide a steady stream of income for investors. This can be particularly attractive in a no-arbitrage market where returns from other asset classes may be lower.
3. Liability management: For corporations and other borrowers, bonds can be used to manage liabilities and ensure that they can meet their debt obligations. Even in a no-arbitrage market, the existence of these liabilities can make bonds an important component of a company's financial strategy.
4. Diversification: Bonds can provide a source of diversification for investors,

prompt:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a process called negotiation. These securities are typically traded on financial markets and are considered liquid assets, meaning they can be easily bought and sold. Examples of negotiable securities include stocks, bonds, and promissory notes.

Negotiable securities are closely related to derivatives, which are financial contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Derivatives can be thought of as agreements between two parties to exchange payments based on the future value of an underlying asset. Common types of derivatives include options, futures, and swaps.

Negotiable securities and derivatives are related in that derivatives can be created on top of negotiable securities. For example, a company might issue a negotiable bond that can be traded on a financial market. An investor can then create a derivative instrument, such as a futures contract, based on the value of that bond. This allows the investor to speculate on the future value of the bond without actually owning the underlying security.

Investors can also use negotiable securities as collateral to create derivatives. For example, an investor might pledge a portfolio of stocks as collateral to secure a loan from a bank. The bank can then create a derivative
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bankruptcy laws follow a "date of valuation" approach, which means that the value of assets at the date of bankruptcy is used to determine their distribution in the bankruptcy case.

This is true for most types of assets, including real estate, personal property, and investments. However, there are some exceptions, such as retirement accounts, which may be valued according to their current value.

The reason for this approach is to provide a more accurate picture of the asset's value at the time of bankruptcy. This can help ensure that the asset is distributed fairly and accurately among creditors.

It's worth noting that the date of valuation can have a significant impact on the outcome of a bankruptcy case. For example, if an asset has decreased in value since the date of bankruptcy, its value may be lower than it would be if its current value were used. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Equation to determine if a stock is oversold and by how much?[/INST]
pred:
There are several oversold extension tools that investors and analysts use to determine if a stock is oversold and by how much. Here are some of the most popular ones:

1. Relative Strength Index (RSI): RSI is a momentum oscillator that measures the speed and change of price movements. The RSI can be used to identify oversold conditions by comparing the stock's price movement to its historical performance. A reading of less than 30 is generally considered oversold.
2. Bollinger Bands: Bollinger Bands are volatility indicators that consist of a moving average and two standard deviations plotted above and below it. When a stock's price breaks below the lower band, it may be considered oversold. The distance between the bands can also be adjusted to suit the investor's preferences.
3. Stochastic Oscillator: The Stochastic Oscillator is a momentum indicator that compares the closing price of a stock to its price range over a given period of time. When the stock's price falls below the middle band, it may be considered oversold.
4. MACD (Moving Average Convergence Divergence): MACD is a momentum indicator that measures the relationship between two moving averages. A crossover below the signal line may indicate an oversold condition
answers: What you are seeking is termed "Alpha", the mispricing in the market. Specifically, Alpha is the price error when compared to the market return and beta of the stock. The EMH also suggests that taxes, human effort and information propagation delays don't exist (i.e. it is wrong). In this scenario, money market rates may increase as investors demand higher returns for tying up their funds in a riskier asset category.

The statement "it is the bank's money not yours" is a common myth surrounding credit card purchases. While it is true that credit card issuers provide the funds for credit card transactions, the idea that the money is not yours is a misconception.

When you make a purchase with a credit card, the merchant is paid immediately, but you don't actually pay for the purchase until the end of the month when your credit card issuer bills you. This means that the money you use to make purchases is not truly "the bank's money," but rather a line of credit extended to you by the bank.

In essence, when you use a credit card, you are borrowing money from the bank to make a purchase. You are then required to repay that amount, along with any interest and fees, when you receive your monthly statement. This means that the money you use to make purchases is still yours, but you are merely borrowing it from the bank and paying it back later.

It's important to understand this relationship between you and your credit card issuer, as it can help you manage your finances more effectively. By tracking your spending and making timely payments, you can avoid accumulating debt and ensure that you always have access to the credit you need when you need it.

In summary, while it is not technically "the bank's

pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm here to provide you with financial knowledge. When a put seller closes early, it means they have exercised their option contract before the expiration date. In this scenario, the buyer's option becomes worthless, and they incur a financial loss.

Here's how it works:

The put buyer purchases an option contract giving them the right to sell their underlying asset (e.g., stock, ETF, or index) at a specified price (strike price) before a specific date (expiration date). If the market price of the underlying asset is lower than the strike price, the put buyer can exercise their option and sell the asset at the higher strike price, thus limiting their loss.

Now, if the put seller closes their option early, they have effectively sold their underlying asset at the strike price, which is higher than the market price. This means the buyer's option becomes worthless, and they incur a financial loss. The loss is calculated by subtracting the strike price from the market price of the underlying asset at the time the option is exercised.

It's worth noting that the put seller may close their option early due to various reasons, such as a change in market conditions or a specific event that affects the underlying asset's price. In some cases, the put seller may close their option
answers: An option is freely tradable, and all options (of the same kind) are equal. If your position is 0 and you sell 1 option, your new position in that option is -1. If the counterparty to your trade buys or sells more options to close, open, or even reopen their position afterwards, that doesn't matter to your position at all. Of course there's also the issue with American and European Options. European Options expire at their due date, but American Options expire at their due date or at any time before their due date if the holder decides they expire. With American Options, if a holder of an American Option decides to exercise the option, someone who is short the same option will be assigned as the counterparty (this is usually random). Expiry is after market close, so if one of your short American Options expires early, you will need to reopen the position the next day. Keep in mind dividends for slightly increased complexity. American and European Options do not in any way refer to the continents they are traded on, or to the location of the companies. These terms simply describe the expiry rules.

What is high trading volume in a stock indicative of? Is high liquidity a good thing or a bad thing?[/INST]
pred:
High trading volume in a stock is indicative of increased market interest in the stock, which can be driven by various factors such as economic changes, company performance, or sentiment shifts. High trading volume can be a good or bad thing depending on the context.

On the positive side, high trading volume can signal a strong and liquid market, making it easier for buyers and sellers to enter and exit positions without significantly affecting stock prices. This can lead to tighter bid-ask spreads, which can reduce transaction costs for investors and improve market efficiency. Furthermore, high trading volume can be a sign of increased liquidity, which can provide a safety net for investors during times of market stress.

However, high trading volume can also be a double-edged sword. Excessive volatility and high trading volume can lead to increased transaction costs, such as brokerage commissions and slippage. This can be particularly problematic for investors with smaller accounts or those who are attempting to execute trades during times of high market activity. Additionally, high trading volume can sometimes be a sign of market manipulation or insider trading, which can undermine investor confidence and lead to price distortions.

In summary, high trading volume can be a positive or negative indicator depending on the context. While it can signal a strong and liquid market, it can also lead to increased
answers: In general, liquidity is a good thing, because it means it is easy for you to buy or sell a stock.   Since high liquidity stocks have a lot of trading, the bid-ask spreads tend to be pretty low.  That means you can go into the market and trade easily and cheaply at just about any time.  For low liquidity stocks, the bid-ask spreads can get pretty high, so it can make it hard or expensive to get into or out of your trades. On the flip side, everyone pays attention to high liquidity stocks, so it's harder to get an edge in your trading.  For a company like Microsoft there are 30-50 full time analysts that cover them, thousands of professional traders and millions of investors in general all reading the same new articles and looking through the same financials as you.  But in low liquidity stocks, there probably aren't any analysts, a few professional traders and maybe a few thousand total investors, so it can be easier to find a good buy (or sell). In general, high liquidity doesn't mean that everyone is selling or everyone is buy, it just means everyone is trading.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Please explain: What exactly is a CDS or “Credit Default Swap”?[/INST]
pred:
A Credit Default Swap (CDS) is a financial derivative instrument that allows investors to purchase protection against potential default risks associated with a borrower's debt obligations. In essence, a CDS is a insurance policy against credit losses.

A CDS transaction involves two parties: a protection buyer and a protection seller. The protection buyer, typically a bank or institutional investor, purchases protection against potential default risks of a reference entity (such as a corporate bond issuer or a sovereign nation) from the protection seller, who is usually a specialized financial institution known as a CDS provider.

In exchange for a premium paid by the protection buyer, the CDS provider agrees to make periodic payments to the protection buyer in the event of a default by the reference entity. The frequency and amount of these payments are predetermined and specified in the CDS contract. The CDS provider absorbs the losses associated with the default, while the protection buyer gains protection against potential losses in their investment portfolio.

CDS can be used to hedge against default risks in various types of debt securities, including corporate bonds, sovereign bonds, and even commercial mortgage-backed securities. They can also be used to speculate on the probability of default by a particular iss
answers: A Credit Default Swap is a derivative, a financial contract with a value dependent upon another asset. A CDS, in essence, is exactly what it sounds like a swap upon default. The typical arrangement is that a holder of non-risk free credit enters into an arrangement with a counterparty to pay the counterparty a portion of the income received from the non-risk free credit in exchange for being able to force the counterparty to deliver risk free credit if the non-risk free credit defaults. Banks use this mechanism to reduce the risk of the loans they produce while packaging them to be resold to investors.  Banks will typically buy CDSes on mortgages and corporate bonds, paying part of the income from interest payments received, to have the right to force counterparties, typically hedge funds and insurance companies, to swap national Treasuries upon the event that the mortgages or corporates default.  The banks receive less income yet are able to take on more inventory to sell to investors so that more loans can be made to borrowers, households and corporations. Hedge funds typically take on more complex arrangements while insurance companies sell CDSes because they are usually overflowing with risk-free assets yet are starved for income.

Network marketing, also known as multi-level marketing (MLM), is a business model in which a company distributors sell products or services to customers through a network of independent distributors. The network of distributors creates a reputation and builds relationships with potential customers and the pay structure is based on a hierarchical commission structure, with higher commissions paid to those who recruit and coach more distributors. The goal of network marketing is to create a large network of distributors who can sell the products or services to customers and also recruit new distributors to join the network.

Network marketing is different from traditional sales in several ways. In traditional sales, the focus is on selling a product or service to a single customer, whereas in network marketing, the focus is on building a network of distributors who can sell the product or service to multiple customers. Network marketing also rewards distributors for recruiting new distributors, creating a hierarchical structure of distributors, with higher-level distributors earning larger commissions based on their ability to recruit and coach new distributors.

Network marketing has been criticized by some for being a pyramid scheme, which is an illegal business model that focuses on recruiting new members with little or no actual product sales. However, legitimate network marketing companies have a product or service to sell to customers and prioritize sales to customers over recruit

answers: The short answer is yes you can, but you have to make sure you do it correctly.
